title: Earned Value Management
description: Master EVM metrics to diagnose cost and schedule performance, forecast final outcomes, and make data-driven project decisions.
objectives: Calculate core EVM metrics: PV (Planned Value), EV (Earned Value), AC (Actual Cost)
Interpret variance indicators: SV (Schedule Variance), CV (Cost Variance) to assess project health
Analyze performance indexes: SPI (Schedule Performance Index), CPI (Cost Performance Index) to predict trends
Apply forecasting formulas: EAC (Estimate at Completion) to make informed cost decisions
Use EVM data to make go/no-go decisions on project continuation

screens.headline: Month 6 Status Report: We've spent $140K of $240K. Are we in trouble?

visual.left: Elena reviewing spreadsheet with red highlights ($140K spent / $240K budget)
visual.right: Alex with project plans showing incomplete sections
visual.center: Large '40% Complete' progress bar next to '$140K Spent' counter

dialogue.text: Alex, you've spent 58% of the budget but Carlos says we're only 40% done. That sounds like a disaster. Prove to me we're not heading for a cost overrun—or tell me how bad it's going to get.

screens.learningHook: Gut feel says 'over budget.' But Earned Value Management reveals the REAL story: Are we behind schedule, over budget, or both? Calculate PV, EV, AC, and use SPI/CPI to diagnose—then forecast EAC to predict the final damage.

screens.title: EVM Analysis: Calculate, Diagnose, Forecast
screens.instructions: Work through 4 sequential scenarios. Calculate metrics, interpret results, and make go/no-go decisions.

scenarios.title: Calculate Planned Value (PV)
scenarios.description: At Month 6 of a 12-month project, we SHOULD be 50% complete according to the schedule. BAC = $240,000.

questions.question: What is the Planned Value (PV) at Month 6?

feedback.correct: Perfect. PV = BAC × Planned % Complete = $240,000 × 50% = $120,000. This is what we SHOULD have accomplished by now.
feedback.incorrect: Review: PV = BAC × Planned % Complete. At Month 6 of 12 months, we should be 50% complete. PV = $240K × 50% = $120K.

questions.question: What does this PV tell us?

options.text: We planned to complete $120K worth of work by Month 6.

feedback.correct: Correct! PV is the baseline—what the schedule says we should have accomplished.
feedback.incorrect: PV measures planned work, not actual spending or work completed.

scenarios.title: Calculate Earned Value (EV) and Cost Variance (CV)
scenarios.description: We've completed 40% of the project. We've spent $140,000 so far. BAC = $240,000.

feedback.correct: Exactly! EV = BAC × % Complete = $240,000 × 40% = $96,000. This is the VALUE of work actually completed.
Perfect! CV = EV - AC = $96,000 - $140,000 = -$44,000. Negative CV means OVER BUDGET.
feedback.incorrect: CV = EV - AC = $96K - $140K = -$44K. Negative means over budget.

options.text: We're $44K over budget. We've spent more than the value we've delivered.
We're $44K under budget. We've saved money.

feedback.incorrect: Negative CV means OVER budget (spent more than value earned).

scenarios.title: Calculate CPI and Forecast EAC
scenarios.description: EV = $96,000, AC = $140,000, BAC = $240,000. Need to forecast final cost.

questions.question: What is the Cost Performance Index (CPI)?

feedback.correct: Perfect! CPI = EV / AC = $96,000 / $140,000 = 0.69. We're getting $0.69 of value for every $1 spent.

questions.question: If this trend continues, what will be the Estimate at Completion (EAC)?

feedback.correct: Excellent! EAC = BAC / CPI = $240,000 / 0.69 ≈ $348,000. If this efficiency continues, we'll finish $108K over budget.

options.text: We're trending toward a $108K overrun ($348K - $240K). We need corrective action NOW.
We're fine. CPI will improve as we complete easier tasks.
We should wait until Month 9 to reassess.

feedback.correct: Correct! EAC forecasts $348K—Elena needs to know immediately.
feedback.incorrect: With CPI = 0.69, waiting makes it worse. Corrective action needed NOW.

scenarios.title: Should Savory Continue the Project?
scenarios.description: PV = $120K, EV = $96K, AC = $140K, CPI = 0.69, EAC = $348K (projected $108K overrun). Elena asks: Should we continue?

options.text: Cancel the project immediately. We're over budget.
Continue as planned. Cost overruns are normal in construction.
Continue with corrective action: 1) Reduce scope (cut patio), 2) Negotiate vendor discounts, 3) Improve cost efficiency on remaining work.
Ask for $108K more budget and continue.

feedback.correct: Perfect decision-making. You used EVM data to inform CORRECTIVE ACTIONS rather than just reporting bad news. This is how PMs use EVM.
feedback.incorrect: Review: EVM should drive corrective actions. Try fixes before canceling or requesting more budget.

blocks.title: The Three Core Metrics (PV, EV, AC)

metrics.name: PV (Planned Value)
metrics.measures: What we SHOULD have done by now (the baseline)

variances.name: Schedule Variance (SV)
variances.interpretation: SV > 0: Ahead | SV < 0: Behind | SV = 0: On schedule

variances.name: Cost Variance (CV)
variances.interpretation: CV > 0: Under budget | CV < 0: Over budget | CV = 0: On budget

indexes.name: Schedule Performance Index (SPI)
indexes.interpretation: SPI > 1.0: Ahead | SPI < 1.0: Behind | SPI = 1.0: On schedule
indexes.example: SPI = $96K / $120K = 0.80 → Earning value at 80% of planned rate

indexes.name: Cost Performance Index (CPI)
indexes.interpretation: CPI > 1.0: Under budget | CPI < 1.0: Over budget | CPI = 1.0: On budget
indexes.example: CPI = $96K / $140K = 0.69 → Getting $0.69 of value per $1 spent

content.insight: Indexes show TRENDS. CPI is critical because it predicts final cost.

blocks.title: Forecasting (What Will the Final Cost Be?)

forecasts.name: Estimate at Completion (EAC)
forecasts.description: Projects final cost if current cost efficiency continues

forecasts.name: Estimate to Complete (ETC)
forecasts.description: How much MORE we need to spend to finish

forecasts.name: Variance at Completion (VAC)
forecasts.description: How much over or under budget at the end

content.insight: EAC is a forecast, not a guarantee. Corrective action changes CPI and thus EAC.

scenario1_correct.text: Good start. Now let's see if we've actually hit that $120K target.

scenario2_correct.text: Now we're getting somewhere. We're $44K over budget and only 40% done. What's the damage at the end?

scenario3_correct.text: This is what I needed. Data-driven forecasting, not guesswork. Show me your corrective action plan.

scenario4_correct.text: This is leadership. You identified the problem with EVM and proposed solutions. Show me a revised EAC with these changes and we'll proceed.

screens.title: Elena's Challenge—Defend Your Decision
screens.context: Three months later (Month 9), Alex has implemented corrective actions: 1) Cut rooftop patio (saved $60K), 2) Renegotiated dining room contract (saved $15K), 3) Improved cost efficiency.

questions.question: Should Elena approve the final phase?

options.text: Cancel the project—we're still over budget
Approve with close monitoring—$29K overrun is manageable improvement from $108K

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned to use Earned Value Management as a DECISION TOOL, not just a reporting mechanism. By calculating PV, EV, AC, CPI, SPI, and EAC, you diagnosed Savory's cost overrun, forecasted the final damage, and recommended corrective actions.
takeaways: PV = Planned Value (what we SHOULD have done by now, per the baseline)
EV = Earned Value (value of work ACTUALLY completed, at budgeted cost)
CV = EV - AC (negative = over budget, positive = under budget)
CPI = EV / AC (< 1.0 = over budget, > 1.0 = under budget)
EAC = BAC / CPI (forecasts final cost based on current efficiency)
EVM drives DECISIONS: diagnose → forecast → take corrective action
